case_name: the appellant v. the State of Bombay

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 552 of 1962 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 552 of 1962. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and decree dated August 22, 1960 of Bombay High Court in appeal No. 432 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated August 22, 1960 of the former Bombay High Court in appeal No. 432 of 1954 from Original Decree.

facts.text: Special Civil Suit No. 6 of 1953 filed by appellant against State of Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Judge, Senior Division, Ahmednagar, Jr,, Special Civil Suit No. 6 of 1953 filed by the appellant against the State of Bombay for a declaration of his right to water

facts.text: Appellant is owner of Shankar Tukaram Karale Rampur Farm at tail-outlet of Godavari Right Bank Canal Distributary No. 17.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the owner of Shankar Tukaram Karale Rampur Farm, situated at the tail-outlet of the Godavari Right Bank Canal Distributary No. 17,

facts.text: Lands originally belonged to Shankar Tukaram Karale.

anchor.surface_text: The lands companyprised in the said Farm originally belonged to Shankar Tukaram Karale, hereinafter called Karale.

facts.text: In 1935, Karale had sugarcane farm of 35 acres owned and 65 acres leased in Ahmednagar District.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1935 the said Karale had a farm for raising sugarcane companyrsisting of 35 acres owned by him and about 65 acres of land taken on lease by him in Ahmednagar District.

facts.text: Karale obtained sanction to irrigate lands from outlet No. 17 of Godavari Right Bank Canal in 1935.

anchor.surface_text: He obtained sanction to irrigate his lands on the outlet No. 17 of the Godavari Right Bank Canal.

facts.text: In 1935, Government of Bombay proposed to reserve area along Distributary Canal as factory area.

anchor.surface_text: In or about the same year the Government of Bombay proposed to reserve certain area along the said Distributary Canal as factory area.

facts.text: Superintending Engineer agreed on July 14, 1939 to exclude Karale's lands from factory area and give perpetual water supply on condition of concentrating holdings at tail outlet and volumetric basis.

anchor.surface_text: After some companyrespondence between the said karale and the Government of Bombay, it was the appellants case, the Superintending Engineer agreed on July 14, 1939, to exclude Karales lands from the factory area and also to give him water perpetually on companydition that he companycentrated all his holdings on the tail outlet of Distributary No. 17 and to take the supply of water on volumetric basis.

facts.text: Karale concentrated his holdings and shifted operations to tail outlet area.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to that arrangement, Karale, by purchase or otherwise, companycentrated his holdings and shifted his operations to that area

facts.text: Water supplied to Karale on agreed volumetric basis.

anchor.surface_text: and he was supplied water on the agreed basis.

facts.text: In April 1948, appellant and Karale entered partnership for the farm, appellant 3/4 share, Karale 1/4.

anchor.surface_text: In or about April 1948, the appellant and Karale entered into a partnership for exporting the said area whereunder the appellant had three- fourths share and the said Karale had one-fourth share.

facts.text: Consent decree dated February 7, 1951 made appellant full owner of partnership assets including lands and right to canal water.

anchor.surface_text: disputes arose between the appellant and Karale in respect of the partnership which culminated in a companysent decree dated February 7, 1951, whereunder the appellant became the full owner of the partnership business with all its assets and liabilities, including the lands and the companypact block and the right to use the canal water.

facts.text: Canal Officer refused to recognize transfer of water right to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: When the appellant applied for the recognition of the transfer, the Canal Officer refused to do so.

facts.text: From April 1952, canal water supply to appellant stopped.

anchor.surface_text: From April 1952 the supply was stopped.

facts.text: Civil Judge dismissed suit holding agreement existed but transfer violated Bombay Tenancy Act.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Civil Judge held that there was a companycluded agreement between the Government and Karale on the, terms alleged by the appellant, but the transfer by Karale of the said right in favour of the appellant was in violation of the provisions of the Bombay Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act, 1948, and, therefore, there was numberlegal transfer of Karales right of water in favour of the appellant. In that view, he dismissed the suit.

facts.text: Bombay High Court held no concluded agreement or did not comply with law, dismissed appeal.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the High Court held that there was neither a companycluded agreement between Karale and the Government number did it companyly with the requirements of law. In the result the appeal was dismissed.

facts.text: Exhibit D-67 and D-68 dated July 14, 1939 record concluded agreement for perpetual water supply to 100 acres on volumetric basis at tail outlet.

anchor.surface_text: Exhibit D-67 reads thus Below Government endorsement No. 3033/36-1 dated the 28th April 1939 No. 4223 of 1939 Poona, 14th July, 1939. Returned with companypliments. The applicant has already been allowed to companytinue his present cane irrigation of 93 acres on outlets 2 and Tail of Distributary 17 of the Godavari Right Bank Canal for one year from 15-2-1939 pending companysideration of his case in detail, in relation to the demand of the Sugar Company formed by Messrs. Jagtap Khilari on this canal and lately named the Changdeo Sugar Factory.

facts.text: Supreme Court held there was a concluded agreement between Government and Karale for water supply.

anchor.surface_text: A fair reading of these two documents leaves numberroom for doubt that a firm agreement was entered into between the Government and Karale in respect of the supply of water to his land to the extent of 100 acres on the tail outlet of Distributary No. 17 of the Godavari Right Bank Canal.

facts.text: Agreement outside Bombay Irrigation Act, void under s.175(3) Government of India Act 1935.

anchor.surface_text: The agreement is void, as it has number companyplied with the provisions of s. 175 3  of the Government of India Act, 1935.

facts.text: Government sent draft agreement to Karale in February 1942 for execution, not executed.

anchor.surface_text: The Government in or about February 1942 sent a draft agreement to Karale for execution regarding the supply of canal water to his farm, but the said Karale did number execute the agreement.

facts.text: In 1950, Government sent another draft agreement, Karale signed with proviso, Government did not execute.

anchor.surface_text: Again during the companytinuance of the partnership between Karale and the appellant, in or about 1950, the Government of Bombay sent another draft agreement to the said Karale for execution.

facts.text: State contended no concluded agreement between Government and Karale.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Bombay filed a written- statement companytending, inter alia, that there was numberconcluded agreement between the Government and Karale embodying the alleged terms stated in the plaint,

facts.text: Karale applied for exclusion of his land from factory area.

anchor.surface_text: Exhibit D-78. which is number dated, was the application filed by Karale to the Chief Minister, P.W.D. and Irrigation Department, Bombay.

facts.text: Appellant filed application in suit for production of documents including correspondence 1935-1939.

anchor.surface_text: When the suit was pending decision of the Civil Court, the appellant filed an application therein for directing the Government to produce, among others, the applications made to the Government from time to time by Karale in respect of supply of water to his farm in the year 1935 and subsequent thereto

anchor.surface_text: A fair reading of these two documents leaves no room for doubt that a firm agreement was entered into between the Government and Karale in respect of the supply of water to his land to the extent of 100 acres on the tail outlet of Distributary No. 17 of the Godavari Right Bank Canal.

arguments.claim: the word 'permanently' refers to supply of water, as cultivation and supply are inextricably connected

anchor.surface_text: It is said that the word permanently refers to cultivation, but not to supply of water. This interpretation makes the entire contract meaningless. Sugar cultivation can be done only with the permission of the department, for sugarcane crop cannot be raised without supply of water from the canal.

arguments.claim: the said agreement was arrived at outside the provisions of the Act

arguments.claim: the contract was made in exercise of executive authority under s.175(3) GOI Act 1935, requiring expression by Governor and execution on his behalf

anchor.surface_text: If so, it follows that the contract entered into between the Government and Karale was a contract made in the exercise of the executive authority of the Province within the meaning of s. 175 3  of the Government of India Act, 1935. The relevant part of s. 175 3  of the Government of India Act, 1935, read All contracts made in the exercise of the executive authority of a Province shall be expressed to be made by the Governor

arguments.claim: provisions of s.175(3) are mandatory; contracts not complying are void (following Seth Bikhraj Jaipuria)

anchor.surface_text: This Court held that the contracts, not having been expressed to be entered into by the ,Governor- General and not having been executed on his behalf, were void. This Court held that the provisions of s. 175 3  of the Government of India Act, 1935, were mandatory and, therefore, the contracts were void.

arguments.claim: Exhibits D-67 and D-68 do not show expression in name of Governor or execution on his behalf; cannot be inferred liberally

anchor.surface_text: Nothing has been placed before us to establish that the Superintending Engineer was legally authorized to enter into such a contract on behalf of the Government nor do the documents ex facie show that the agreement was expressed to be made in the name of the Provincial Government.

holdings.text: A fair reading of these two documents leaves no room for doubt that a firm agreement was entered into between the Government and Karale in respect of the supply of water to his land to the extent of 100 acres on the tail outlet of Distributary No. 17 of the Godavari Right Bank Canal.

anchor.surface_text: A fair reading of these two documents leaves no room for doubt that a firm agreement was entered into between the Government and Karale in respect of the supply of water to his land to the extent of 100 acres on the tail outlet of Distributary No. 17 of the Godavari Right Bank Canal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Exhibits D-67 and D-68, along with context of prior correspondence and Karale's acceptance, unequivocally record the agreement.

holdings.text: Exs. D-67 and D-68, read together, record a concluded agreement between the Superintending Engineer, acting on the orders of the Minister of Public Works Department, on the one hand and Karale on the other, agreeing to supply water so long as Karale had cane cultivation in the concentrated area.

anchor.surface_text: It is said that the word permanently refers to cultivation, but not to supply of water. This interpretation makes the entire contract meaningless. Sugar cultivation can be done only with the permission of the department, for sugarcane crop cannot be raised without supply of water from the canal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects narrow reading of 'permanently'; cultivation and water supply inextricably linked, implying permanent supply conditional on payment.

holdings.text: the agreement in question was arrived at outside the provisions of the Act and, therefore, it squarely falls within the scope of s. 175(3) of the Government of India Act, 1935.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal raises a question a far-reaching importance as regards the scope of the executive authority exercised by the Governor under the Government of India Act, 1935 but, we are relieved of the duty to express our opinion on that question in this appeal

holdings.reasoning_summary: No application under s.27 to Canal-Officer; Act and Rules lack provision for permanent supply or factory area exclusion; effected via Minister's verbal orders.

holdings.text: Such an agreement fell outside the provisions of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: by a reference to the Bombay Canal Rules, 1934, made in exercise of the powers conferred on the State Government under s. 70 (e) of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absence of statutory mechanism in ss.27-30 or Rules for the agreement's terms; treated as executive action beyond Canal-Officer powers.

holdings.text: the contract entered into between the Government and Karale was a contract made in the exercise of the executive authority of the Province within the meaning of s. 175(3) of the Government of India Act, 1935.

anchor.surface_text: If so, it follows that the contract entered into between the Government and Karale was a contract made in the exercise of the executive authority of the Province within the meaning of s. 175 3  of the Government of India Act, 1935. The relevant part of s. 175 3  of the Government of India Act, 1935, read All contracts made in the exercise of the executive authority of a Province shall be expressed to be made by the Governor

holdings.reasoning_summary: Outside Act, hence executive authority; requires Governor's name expression and authorized execution.

holdings.text: The agreement is void, as it has not complied with the provisions of s. 175(3) of the Government of India Act, 1935.

anchor.surface_text: The agreement is void, as it has not complied with the provisions of s. 175(3) of the Government of India Act, 1935.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Documents lack expression in Governor's name or execution on his behalf; no proof of Superintending Engineer's authorization; s.175(3) mandatory per Seth Bikhraj Jaipuria v. Union of India and New Marine Coal Co.; distinguished Rallia Ram.

precedents.citation: Seth Bikhraj Jaipuria v. Union of India 1

anchor.surface_text: Seth Bikhraj Jaipuria v. Union of India 1 . There, the Divisional Superintendent, East Indian Railway, placed certain orders with the appellant for the supply of foodgrains for the employees of the said Railway. The orders were not expressed to be made in the name of the Governor -General and was not executed on behalf of the Governor General as required by s. 175 3 of the Government of India Act, 1935.

precedents.case_name: Seth Bikhraj Jaipuria v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: provisions of s. 175 3 of the Government of India Act, 1935, are mandatory and contracts not expressed to be made by the Governor-General and not executed on his behalf are void
precedents.cited_holding: the contracts, not having been expressed to be entered into by the Governor-General and not having been executed on his behalf, were void

precedents.citation: New Marine Coal Co. v. The Union of India 2

anchor.surface_text: New Marine Coal Co. v. The Union of India 2 . Reliance is placed by the  1  1962 2 C.R. 880.  2  1964 2 S.C.R. 859. 1000 learned counsel for the appellant on the decision of this Court in Union of India v. Rallia Ram  1  in support of his contention that though ex facie Exs. D-67 and D-68 do number show that the contract was expressed to be made in the name of the Governor, the said fact companyld be inferred from the recitals.

precedents.case_name: New Marine Coal Co. v. The Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: followed the decision in Seth Bikhraj Jaipuria v. Union of India holding contracts void under s. 175 3 of the Government of India Act, 1935

precedents.citation: Union of India v. Rallia Ram  1

anchor.surface_text: Union of India v. Rallia Ram  1  in support of his contention that though ex facie Exs. D-67 and D-68 do number show that the contract was expressed to be made in the name of the Governor, the said fact companyld be inferred from the recitals. There, the goods offered to be sold belonged to the Government of India. A tender numberice was issued by the Government of India, Department of Food  Division 111 , in the name of the Chief Director of Purchases.

precedents.case_name: Union of India v. Rallia Ram
precedents.cited_proposition: contract can be inferred to be expressed to be made by and executed on behalf of the Governor-General from recitals and context even if not ex facie stated
precedents.cited_holding: the correspondence between the parties ultimately resulting in the acceptance letter amounted to a contract expressed to be made by the Government and, therefore, by the Governor-General

anchor.surface_text: Seth Bikhraj Jaipuria's case 2 . On a fair reading of the correspondence this Court construed that the contract was entered into on behalf of the Governor-General and expressed to be made in his name. Can it be said that in the present case Exs. D-67 and D-68 disclose that the Superintending Engineer was authorized to enter into a companytract of the nature mentioned therein on behalf of the Provincial Government and that the companytract was expressed to be made in the name of the Governor?  1  1964 3 S.C.R. 164.  2  1962 2 S.C.R. 880. 1001 Nothing has been placed before us to establish that the Superintending Engineer was legally authorized to enter into such a companytract on behalf of the Government number do the documents ex jacie show that the agreement was expressed to be made in the name of the Provincial Government.

precedents.case_name: Seth Bikhraj Jaipuria v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: principle that provisions of s. 175 3 are mandatory and Rallia Ram does not depart from it

anchor.surface_text: The agreement is void, as it has not complied with the provisions of s. 175 3  of the Government of India Act, 1935. In this view, it is not necessary to express our opinion on other interesting questions raised in this case.

outcome.relief_summary: Agreement for perpetual supply of canal water held void due to non-compliance with s. 175(3) of Government of India Act, 1935; appellant's claim for declaration, specific performance and damages denied

anchor.surface_text: A fair reading of these two documents leaves no room for doubt that a firm agreement was entered into between the Government and Karale in respect of the supply of water to his land to the extent of 100 acres on the tail outlet of Distributary No. 17 of the Godavari Right Bank Canal.

The agreement is void, as it has not complied with the provisions of s. 175 3  of the Government of India Act, 1935. In this view, it is not necessary to express our opinion on other interesting questions raised in this case.

anchor.surface_text: If so, it follows that the contract entered into between the Government and Karale was a contract made in the exercise of the executive authority of the Province within the meaning of s. 175 3  of the Government of India Act, 1935. The relevant part of s. 175 3  of the Government of India Act, 1935, read All contracts made in the exercise of the executive authority of a Province shall be expressed to be made by the Governor
